title: 108_hr2601
content: The "Public Domain Enhancement Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section of the Act is also included. The Congress finds that the copyright clause in the United States Constitution grants the power to promote the progress of science and arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times, providing an economic incentive for creating and disseminating ideas. Copyright provides authors with an economic incentive to create new works and promotes society's interest in the free flow of ideas, information, and commerce. The limited copyright term ensures that the public will not be permanently deprived of the fruits of an artist's labor. "The copyright term is limited to prevent permanent deprivation of the fruits of an artist's labor. Both commercial and noncommercial creators rely on a healthy public domain for economic value and availability of works." Some rely on public domain for economic value and availability of works, while others use it for educational and cultural purposes. Media sources like the World Wide Web also benefit from the freedom of public domain. Current law grants copyright protection to works published as early as 1923, but the majority of older works are no longer commercially available. Only 2 percent of works between 55 and 75 years old retain commercial value. Schools, museums, and libraries use public domain works for educational and cultural purposes, while media sources like the World Wide Web benefit from the freedom of public domain content. Under current law, abandoned works published as early as 1923 are no longer commercially available. Only 2 percent of works between 55 and 75 years old retain commercial value. This prevents entities from utilizing and preserving these abandoned works. Abandoned works published as early as 1923 will not enter the public domain for many years, hindering their utilization and preservation. This contradicts the original intent of the copyright system and deprives the public of valuable historical and educational resources. The copyright system hinders the public domain access to abandoned works, contrary to the original intent of the Constitution and Copyright Act. A mechanism is needed for abandoned American copyrights to enter the public domain. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE FEE FOR PUBLISHED UNITED STATES WORKS. The definition of "United States work" in section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for sections 306 and 411. Section 302 of title 17, United States Code, regarding the duration of copyright for works created on or after January 1, 1978, is amended to include section 306. Section 303(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include section 306 for works created but not published or copyrighted before January 1, 1978. Section 303(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include section 306 for works created but not published or copyrighted before January 1, 1978. Amendments include changes to the language regarding copyright and the conditions under which it applies. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include section 306 for subsisting copyrights, with changes to the language regarding copyright conditions. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include section 306 for subsisting copyrights, with changes to the language regarding copyright conditions. In section 306, certain amendments are made to subparagraphs and paragraphs related to copyright expiration. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include section 306 for subsisting copyrights, with changes to the language regarding copyright conditions. Subparagraphs and paragraphs related to copyright expiration are amended, including the insertion of new sections and maintenance fee provisions. The Register of Copyrights will charge a $1 fee for maintaining the copyright of published United States works, due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter until the end of the copyright term. The fee for maintaining copyright is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Failure to pay the fee within 6 months after the due date will result in the copyright expiring. Ancillary or promotional works connected to the maintained work will also have their copyright maintained. The maintenance fee for copyright is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Failure to pay the fee within 6 months after the due date will result in the copyright expiring. Ancillary or promotional works connected to the maintained work will also have their copyright maintained. The form for the maintenance fee must be prescribed by the Register of Copyrights and conform with section 409. It can also be used to satisfy registration provisions if accompanied by the required deposit, fee, and additional identifying material. The registration provisions of sections 408 and 409 require a prescribed deposit, fee, and additional identifying material. A conforming amendment was made to the table of sections for chapter 3 of title 17, United States Code. Section 708(a) of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a maintenance fee for published United States works. Additionally, a new duty for the Register is outlined. The Register of Copyrights must establish procedures to ease the submission of forms and make the information easily accessible to the public within 12 months of the Act's enactment.
